ðŸ§µFor those who don't know, this has been in the works for a while.

There have been plans in the works to close down and consolidate some of the libraries with NASA.

But the closure of the Goddard library was never part of the plan.

Planning was being done to make Goddard the hub/main library.

I think the primary driver is cheap *energy*, not labor.

Southern states have shitty environmental regulations and a higher cultural tolerance for dirty sources like fossil fuels.

reply_context.text:
They could put these data centers in areas of high altitude that are naturally colder or underwater in cold current areas.

Other countries have been doing this.

But they're putting them in southern states where labor is cheap, unions are slim, and elected officials are owned.

Each time you ask an AI chatbot a question, it sends a request to a data center and strains an increasingly scarce resource: water. 

A Bloomberg investigation in May found that data centers that power AI are increasingly being built in highly water-stressed places.

posts.text: My general take is that computer science is the study of generalized problem solving, and software engineering is the art of managing complexity. The fundamental principles that underlie these crafts are broadly applicable across domains, whether someone expects to be writing code or not.
